li.p: Can we find higher degree polynomial approximations for functions other than f(x) = e^x?
How are the coefficients of the polynomial approximation to a function f(x) near a = 0 determined by the values of the various derivatives of f, evaluated at a = 0?
Can we find polynomial approximations to a given function f that are centered at a point other than a = 0?

introduction.p:
In Activity, we investigated a degree 3 polynomial approximation T(x) to f(x) = e^x near a = 0. To do so, we chose the conditions T(0) = f(0), T'(0) = f'(0), T''(0) = f''(0), and T'''(0) = f'''(0). Starting with T(x) = k_0 + k_1 x + k_2 x^2 + k^3 x^3 and f(x) = e^x and finding the needed derivatives and evaluating them at a = 0 led us to the results in Table
Formulas and values for f(x) = e^x and T(x) = k_0 + k_1 x + k_2 x^2 + k_3 x^3.
f(x)= e^x T(x)= k_0 + k_1 x + k_2 x^2 + k_3 x^3
f'(x)= e^x T'(x)= k_1 + 2 k_2 x + 3 k_3 x^2
f''(x)= e^x T''(x)= 2 k_2 + 6 k_3 x
f''(x)= e^x T''(x)= 6 k_3
f(0)= 1 T(0)= k_0
f'(0)= 1 T'(0)= k_1
f''(0)= 1 T''(0)= 2k_2
f''(0)= 1 T''(0)= 6k_3

Equating the function and derivative values of f and T at a = 0, we found that k_0 = 1, k_1 = 1, 2k_2 = 1, 6k_3 = 1 and therefore k_0 = 1, k_1 = 1, k_2 = \frac{1}{2}, k_3 = \frac{1}{6} so that T(x) = 1 + x + \frac{1}{2}x^2 + \frac{1}{6}x^3. Moreover, plotting f and T near a = 0, we see in the Figure that the interval of accuracy for a tolerance of 0.1 is about -1.2 \le x \le 1.2.
The function f(x)=e^x and its degree 3 Taylor approximation T(x) = 1 + x + \frac{1}{2}x^2 + \frac{1}{6}x^3 near the point (0,f(0)).

More precisely, we might compute that |f(-1.16) - T(-1.16)| \approx 0.0608 and |f(1.16) - T(1.16)| \approx 0.0970, which helps us see the degree 3 approximation is very accurate on an interval wider than |x| \lt 1.
In this section, we will learn how we can find higher degree approximations for functions other than f(x) = e^x, as well as how to center the approximation at a value other than a = 0.

subsection.title: Taylor polynomials
subsection.p:
In our work so far in Chapter, we have found several different approximations of two important functions: e^x and \sin(x). In Section, we saw that near a = 0
e^x \approx 1 + x (the degree 1 approximation);
e^x \approx 1 + x + \frac{1}{2}x^2 (the degree 2 approximation); and
e^x \approx 1 + x + \frac{1}{2}x^2 + \frac{1}{6}x^3 (the degree 3 approximation).
Moreover, we found that as the degree of the approximation increased, the polynomial approximation got more accurate by being closer to the e^x on a wider interval.

In Preview, we saw further that
\sin(x) \approx x (the degree 1 approximation); and
\sin(x) \approx x - \frac{1}{6}x^3 (the degree 3 approximation).

We can also notice that the linear approximation is embedded within the quadratic approximation, and the quadratic approximation within the cubic one, and so on. These observations naturally lead us to consider approximations of arbitrary degree n in order to generate more accurate approximations for any function with a sufficient number of derivatives. We thus define the Taylor polynomial of degree n centered at a = 0 as follows.

definition.statement: Let n be a natural number and let f be a function with at least n derivatives at a = 0. The degree n Taylor polynomial of f centered at a = 0 is the function T_n(x) = c_0 + c_1x + c_2x^2 + \cdots + c_nx^n that satisfies T_n(0) = f(0), T_n’(0) = f’(0), T_n’’(0) = f’’(0), \ldots, T_n^{(n)}(0) = f^{(n)}(0).

subsection.p: By definition, T_n is the polynomial whose function and first n derivative values at a = 0 match the function value and all n derivative values of f at a = 0.

The n+1 equations T_n(0) = f(0), T_n’(0) = f’(0), T_n’’(0) = f’’(0), \ldots, T_n^{(n)}(0) = f^{(n)}(0) enable us to determine the coefficients c_0, c_1, \ldots, c_n in terms of the values of the various derivatives of f. Indeed, by taking the various derivatives of T_n(x), evaluating those derivatives at a = 0, and setting each result equal to the corresponding derivative value of f, we see the results in the Table.

table.title: Finding the coefficients c_0, c_1, \ldots, c_n in a Taylor polynomial.

cell.m: T_n(x) = c_0 + c_1x + c_2x^2 + c_3x^3 + c_4x^4 + \cdots + c_nx^n

subsection.p:
We see the pattern that for each derivative we take, each coefficient c_i gets multiplied by what was formerly the corresponding power to which x was raised. For example, the repeated derivatives of x^4 are 4x^3, 4 \cdot 3 x^2, 4 \cdot 3 \cdot 2 x, and finally 4 \cdot 3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1. By the time we get to the fourth derivative of x^4, only a constant remains, and that constant is the factorialFor any positive whole number n, its factorial, n! is the product of all of the positive whole numbers less than or equal to n: n! = n \cdot (n-1) \cdot (n-2) \cdot \cdots \cdot 3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1.
\frac{d^4}{dx^4}\left[ x^4 \right] = 4 \cdot 3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1 = 4!
From the rightmost column of Table, we now see how the values of c_0, c_1, \ldots, c_n are determined by the values of f and its derivatives evaluated at a = 0, scaled by corresponding factorials. In particular,
c_0 = f(0), c_1 = f’(0), c_2 = \frac{f’’(0)}{2!}, c_3 = \frac{f’’’(0)}{3!}, c_4 = \frac{f^{(4)}(0)}{4!}, \ldots, c_n = \frac{f^{(n)}(0)}{n!}
This enables us to find the Taylor polynomial of degree n for any function f by computing the polynomial's coefficients via finding the values of f(0), f'(0), \ldots, f^{(n)}(0).

assemblage.title: Finding the degree n Taylor polynomial of f centered at a = 0
assemblage.p: If f is a function with at least n derivatives at a = 0, then the degree n Taylor polynomial of f centered at a = 0, T_n(x), is given by T_n(x) = c_0 + c_1x + c_2x^2 + \cdots + c_nx^n where each coefficient c_k is given by c_k = \frac{f^{(k)}(0)}{k!}.

example.title: The degree 5 Taylor polynomial of f(x) = \ln(1+x)

statement.p: Find the degree 5 Taylor polynomial centered at a = 0 for the function f(x) = \ln(1+x).

solution.p: To find the degree 5 Taylor polynomial, we need to compute f(0), f'(0), f''(0) \ldots, f^{(5)}(0), so we first find the first through fifth derivatives of f in the left column of Table, and then evaluate those derivatives at a = 0 in the right column.

table.title: Finding the derivatives of f(x) = \ln(1+x) at a = 0.

subsection.p:
From our work in Example, we can also see a pattern that arises and thus we expect the general degree n Taylor polynomial centered at a = 0 for f(x) = \ln(1+x) to be
T_n(x) = x - \frac{1}{2}x^2 + \frac{1}{3}x^3 - \cdots + (-1)^{n-1}\frac{1}{n}x^n.
For many familiar functions, a pattern emerges in their derivatives that enables us to find the general form of the degree n Taylor polynomial.

In Activity, we see that the degree 6 Taylor approximation of the cosine function at a = 0 is
\cos(x) \approx 1 - \frac{1}{2!}x^2 + \frac{1}{4!}x^4 - \frac{1}{6!}x^6.
We can do similar work to extend what we found in Preview Activity and observe that
\sin(x) \approx x - \frac{1}{3!}x^3 + \frac{1}{5!}x^5 - \frac{1}{7!}x^7
is the degree 7 Taylor approximation of the sine function at a = 0. Furthermore, as we saw in Section,
e^x \approx 1 + x + \frac{1}{2!}x^2 + \frac{1}{3!}x^3 + \frac{1}{4!}x^4
so we now have higher degree Taylor approximations for e^x, \sin(x), and \cos(x) that exhibit interesting patterns in their coefficients. We will explore these further in **Section**.

subsection.title: Taylor polynomial approximations centered at an arbitrary value a
subsection.p: In all of our work so far in Chapter, we have focused on approximating functions such as f(x) = e^x, f(x) = \sin(x), f(x) = \ln(1+x), and f(x) = \cos(x) near a = 0. But we could instead be interested in the behavior of some function f near a = 5, or be interested in a function f that wasn't even defined at a = 0, so next we consider how we can generalize our earlier work to Taylor polynomial approximations at any value a.

From our early studies in Section, we know that at any input value x = a where a function f has a first derivative, f has a tangent line approximation L(x) = f(a) + f'(a)(x-a) that satisfies f(x) \approx L(x) for x values near a. Provided that f has a second derivative at x=a, we can generate a quadratic approximation near a for f like we found at a = 0 for f(x)=e^x in Activity, and as long as f has a third derivative at x=a, we can even find a cubic approximation (as in Activity). In developing such an approximation, our guiding principle is the same as with our work at a = 0: we'll require that at the input value a, the original function's output and its derivatives' outputs match the corresponding approximation's output and derivatives' output.

Building on the form of the tangent line approximation, L(x) = f(a) + f’(a)(x-a), it is natural for us to consider a quadratic approximation of form T_2(x) = c_0 + c_1(x-a) + c_2 (x-a)^2, and a cubic approximation of form T_3(x) = c_0 + c_1 (x-a) + c_2 (x-a)^2 + c_3(x-a)^3, and so on. Indeed, we define the degree n Taylor Polynomial centered at a more generally as follows.

definition.statement: Let n be a natural number and let f be a function with at least n derivatives at a. The degree n Taylor polynomial of f centered at a is the function T_n(x) = c_0 + c_1(x-a) + c_2(x-a)^2 + \cdots + c_n(x-a)^n that satisfies T_n(a) = f(a), T_n’(a) = f’(a), T_n’’(a) = f’’(a), \ldots, T_n^{(n)}(a) = f^{(n)}(a).

subsection.p: Similar to the situation when a = 0, it follows that we can find the coefficients c_k of the Taylor polynomial in terms of the various derivatives of f evaluated at a.

assemblage.title: Finding the degree n Taylor polynomial of f centered at a
assemblage.p: If f is a function with at least n derivatives at a, then the degree n Taylor polynomial of f centered at a, T_n(x), is given by T_n(x) = c_0 + c_1(x-a) + c_2(x-a)^2 + \cdots + c_n(x-a)^n where each coefficient c_k is given by c_k = \frac{f^{(k)}(a)}{k!}.

li.p: Provided that a function f(x) has n derivatives at a selected input value x = a, we can find a degree n polynomial T_n(x) that approximates f(x) near a by requiring that T_n(a) = f(a), T_n'(a) = f'(a), T_n''(a) = f''(a), \ldots, T_n^{(n)}(a) = f^{(n)}(a).

When a = 0, we call the degree n polynomial approximation, T_n(x) to a function f(x) near 0 the degree n Taylor polynomial of f centered at a = 0, and if we write T_n(x) = c_0 + c_1 x + c_2 x^2 + \cdots c_n x^n it follows that the coefficients c_k are determined by the values of the various derivatives of f(x) evaluated at 0 according to the formula c_k = \frac{f^{(k)}(0)}{k!}.

Just as we can consider any function f that has n derivatives, we can also consider any input value a at which those n derivatives exist, and find a polynomial approximation that satisfies T_n(a) = f(a), T_n'(a) = f'(a), T_n''(a) = f''(a), \ldots, T_n^{(n)}(a) = f^{(n)}(a). We call the degree n polynomial approximation, T_n(x) to the function f(x) near a the degree n Taylor polynomial of f centered at a, and if we write T_n(x) = c_0 + c_1 (x-a) + c_2 (x-a)^2 + \cdots c_n (x-a)^n it follows that the coefficients c_k are determined by the values of the various derivatives of f(x) evaluated at a according to the formula c_k = \frac{f^{(k)}(a)}{k!}.
